column6: References for oldest fossil(s) and discussion of calibration

column7: Eritherium was originally described as a stem proboscidean (99), but is the sister group to Proboscidea, Sirenia, or Tethytheria in more recent analyses (102).

column3: Phosphatherium escuilliei is the oldest unequivocal stem proboscidean
Corumictis wolsani is the oldest stem mustelid (Paterson et al. 2020)
column7: Corumictis wolsani is the oldest stem mustelid and is known from the early Oligocene (Rupelian). The top of the early Oligocene is 27.82 Ma based on the International Chronostratigraphic Chart (v 2021/07)

Previously the ursid Cephalogale has been used to constrain the crown group Actoidea to a minimum of 28.1 Ma or the top of the early Oligocene (Rupelian) (101). The oldest stem mustelid (Corumictis wolsani) is also known from the early Oligocene (108), as are fossil remains of the stem pinniped Enaliarctos tedfordi from the Yaquina Formation in Oregon (109) that were dated to 30.6 – 27.4 Ma based on a paleomagnetic and K:Ar study (6). We used a date of 27.82 Ma for the top of the early Oligocene based on the most recent version of the International Chronostratigraphic Chart (v 2021/07)

column3: Tachypteron franzeni, Witwatia sigei, Dizzya exsultans
Tachypteron franzeni, Witwatia sigei, Dizzya exsultans

column7: While Adunator ladae most likely represents a stem erinaceid fossil, we also cite the more confidently assigned Litolestes ignotus following (119). This fossil is from the Ravenscrag Formation in Canada which is dated to the Tiffanian – the lower boundary of which is given as the Selandian (Paleobiology Database). This gives a minimum bound of 61.6 Ma in line with the ICS. (119) use the base of the Danian as the maximum bound, 66 Ma.
Maximum age is based on the possibility that mesonychids are crown cetartiodactyls.

The oldest crown cetacean fossil is Mystacodon selenensis from the Late Eocene of Peru (122). This fossil gives a new minimum bound for this clade of 36.4 Ma – which (122) derived from assessing sedimentation rates, a result corroborated by biostratigraphic and biochronological analyses.
column8: Stratigraphic Bounding. (101) used stratigraphic bounding of two stages to give a maximum bound of 47.8 Ma.

column3: Moronocetus parvus is a stem balaenid and has a minimum age of 15.97 Ma; maximum based on the age of the oldest stem mysticete (Mystacodon)
column7: Mauicetus parki is older than Morenocetus (25.2-23.0 Ma) but may be crown mysticete (125) or a stem mysticete (126).
Sifrhippus is know from the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM) (130).

Cambaylophus from the early Eocene Cambay Shale formation from western India is the oldest known ceratomorph. The minimum for this node is given on the basis that Kapur and Bajpai (131) state that the mammals from this formation significantly predates the Second Eocene Thermal Maximum (SETM) dated at 53.7 Ma. The maximum bound for this node is given by stratigraphic bounding of two stages (Thanetian and Selandian), 61.6 Ma following (132).

column3: Teilhardina brandti is from the PETM of North America at ~56 Ma (Morse et al. 2019)
column7: Calibration is actually for Haplorhini but Tarsius is missing from data set

The oldest fossil attributable to this node is now Panamacebus transitus from the Las Cascadas Formation of the Panama Canal Basin (136). Magmatic Zircons from about 0.25m below the primate bearing horizon yield an age estimate for this layer of 20.93 ± 0.17 Ma. Conservatively, the upper bound of the Aquitanian should be used as the minimum bound for this node, 20.44 Ma.

Stevens et al (137) describe Rukwapithecus fleaglei as the earliest crown catarrine and phylogenetic analyses place it within the Nyanzapithicine clade. Although this relationship is not robustly supported in Stevens et al.'s (137) analysis, later analyses aimed at placing the much more extensive cranial remains of Nyanzapithecus alesi among catarrhines, also recovered Rukwapithecus among the Nyanzapithicine clade (138). Based on high precision CA-TIMS U-Pb zircon dating this of this fossil locality provides a minimum constraint of 25.22 Ma (137) to this node.

Microcolobus tugenesis is the oldest fossil attributable to this node (119). However a recently discovered specimen, from the exceptionally calibrated Kabasero type section of the Ngoragora Formation, is estimated at the older age of 12.49 ± 0.02 Ma (139)compared to the more recent specimen referenced in Springer et al. (135). This yields a minimum constraint of 12.47 Ma for this node.

column8: Stratigraphic Bounding, Phylogenetic Uncertainty, Phylogenetic Bracketing.

column2: Additional Calibrations for the 241 species tree

column7: Maximum follows McGowen et al. (148) and is based on the oldest known stem delphinoid (Kentriodon pernix) based on the Geisler et al. (149) analysis with constraints.
The maximum age assumes that crown Hominidae is unlikely to be older than the stem hominoid Kamoyapitheus (151). The maximum age for this genus is 27.8 million years (152).
First appearance of Stirtonia is at 12.8 Ma (151, 160)

The oldest fossils attributable to this node are Plesiobalaenoptera quarantellii from Northern Italy and Incakujira anillodefuego from Peru both from the Tortonian of the Late Miocene – yielding a minimum bound of 7.246 Ma. The paratype of Incakujira originates from the ‘upper Isurus [Cosmopolitodus] zone’, thought to most likely be the AGL level, which has been estimated age range of 7.5-7.3 Ma. Here we use the upper boundary of the Tortonian 7.246 Ma to reflect this uncertainty.

column8: An upper bound of 131.5Mya (‘Benton2009 constraint’) was placed on Placentalia (root) based on the well documented fossil species Eomaia (85) and Sinodelphys (86), estimated to be Aptian or Barremian in age (87). A conservative estimate of 131.5Mya is used to reflect the uncertainty around the dating of the horizons from which these fossils are derived (87).
The upper 95% confidence interval from (6) was used to place an upper bound on Placentalia (root).
